The best WW2 FPS ever made. It's a blend of casual and simulation game elements, briding a gap between ARMA and Call of Duty. Most servers are on realism, which is the most difficult game mode for new players to adjust to. The difficulty curve is steep but it's worth it and offers a unique gameplay that can't be found elsewhere. Both Stalingrad and Rising Storm are great, but Rising Storm is a little bit better.  You will:  -Die a lot -Be a rifleman -Get killed by guys you had the drop on  Then somewhere along the way you'll learn how to headshot a guy from 100-200m away with the basic rifle.

Unfortunately I have to not recommend this game. The game mechanics are bad and there's no way around it. It is very hard to distinguish friend from foe, and I'm sure players will say 'oh well hey that's realistic'....yeah well great its also stupid and leads to teamkills. Particularly the pacific maps in the dark...might as well just close your eyes and shoot. Also the movement of your soldier is clunky. Call of Duty United Offensive had MUCH better player movement that was smooth and you actually survived more than 30 seconds. Many maps you get killed without even seeing the enemy. And the vehicles are very hard to maneuver and shoot. Again I suppose all of this was done in the attempt of making the game 'realistic' but it really is just a clusterfudge. You can play this game for hours and not feel any sense of accomplishment or purpose. So with that, I'm done playing it and certainly glad I only spend $5 on it.

Worst Netcode I've ever seen utilized in any game, period. Numerous people have reported issues with immense lag, high latency, the game registering those lag spikes as speed hacks and subsequently banning said player for a round. Their response?   'Its your WiFi.'  Well what if I'm on a wired connection?  'There is no issue.'  This is their stance and they outright refuse to acknowledge this issue making the game unplayable for a large portion of paying customers, including myself. Just google it and see the many many forum threads concerning this issue. If the user says they're not on a wireless connection, they just discount their problem as being with their ISP. I garauntee you, It is not my connection (30mb down - 5mb up - located in Central Texas), I can connect to ANY other game, server or service with no issues except when it comes to (literally) any RO2 server. You cannot, and likely will not find a server that is under 100ms ping, and its very evident. Even when you do, you'll encounter spikes and fits of lag which eventually leads to your session ban.   In a game where one bullet kills and accuracy is everything... a netcode issue rendering the game UNPLAYABLE, is UNACCEPTABLE.  Don't waste your time or, like me, money.

There are many assets that provide a great audiovisual experience. The graphical effects and sounds are perfectly implemented to set the mood and theme of a World War II simulation, grabbing the player's full attention in immersive and tense scenarios. All of the official maps are also beautifully crafted, with much attention to detail, including good quality textures and tactical environments. Since this is a multiplayer only game, that is where it all starts falling apart. Firstly, the developers opted to use the archaic, erroneous, and intrusive PunkBuster anti-cheat service in the game. Not only is it extremely innacurate and unreliable, it also requires its own separate installation onto your system; which means it will force itself to run in the background, in addition to the game client. Secondly, the server browser and in-game pings differ by at least 30 or 40, every time. In other words, the ping being shown in the server browser is always at least 30 or 40 lower than what it actually is in-game. This is a problem that has been reported in both the Steam and official game forums for a long while, without any response by the developers. Thirdly, even though there is an average of 1276 concurrent players in the last 30 days at the time of this writing, finding a populated server with a tolerable ping is not easy. The few servers available with a playable ping (100 or less) have the low artificial intelligence bots taking place of the absent human players, which brings down the game's fun factor to an unbearably low level. In addition to the lack of active servers, when there are people playing on a full server, many player pings are in the 200s, and some in the 300s. What could have been a great, engrossing, realistic experience ends up being marred by all of its technical online problems. While one may find adequate multiplayer conditions to play the game properly from time to time, I have found that this happens very rarely. What you will find are high ping servers with a small human population and a high bot population, with the occasional populated high ping server with human players whose pings are well into the 100s, 200s, and even 300s. A multiplayer only game should never be played in those conditions. If you are able to find a good server with people playing, there are many fun and fulfilling hours to be had. Too bad these ideal conditions are few and far between.  Rising Storm/Red Orchestra 2 Multiplayer is mediocre.

Well, I really just don't see the appeal of this game. For some reason it's wildly popular and recommended by most.   After completing the tutorial, i jumped into a match and was immediately lost and disoriented. When you spawn the objectives flash VERY briefly then disappear and force you to hold a button... I like knowing where I am going.   The lack of a spotting feature and drab, bland, below-average poorly textured graphics hide soldiers very well. Combine that with the all teh weapons which are basically 1 hit kill and it allows stackers/hackers to camp/spawn camp the sht out of you. I abhor rubber bullet games like Quake Wars which permit aimbots and stackers to steamroll but there has to be a balance.   There is no freedom of class as they are all limited via a maximum cap so the good classes like sniper are usually always taken. The classes/roles are also basically carbon-copies of each other with weapons/equipment varying little.   The animation is clunky and average at best. The weapon sounds, while I am not disputing their realism or lack thereof, are lacking in bass and volume and are dull and boring.  The low quality does permit large scale battles of 64 players which can be nice. However, the maps are basically rectangular chokepoints made for defenders to farm.  RO has a a very 'indie' vibe to it and is not at all a AAA game.  5.75/10

Be very careful when deciding whether or not you should buy this game. I’ve purchased it and found it to be a massive let-down. The game has a distinct lack of features, is very difficult to learn, and is a very frustrating game to play.  The game extremely confusing to play; upon joining a server for the first time, I found it impossible to find any enemies. I searched the map for at least 15 minutes before being taken out by a sniper in the distance. Upon re-spawning, I didn’t have any issues finding enemies; however, I did have issues killing them. Every time I ran towards the enemy lines, I would just get gunned down every time. This was a very frustrating experience; because I am used to other similar games (such as Call of Duty) I was using the normal tactic commonly found in COD. This, for whatever reason, is not effective in Red Orchestra 2, and instead you must camp and wait for enemies to come into your line of sight. The most frowned upon “tactic” used in Call of Duty is the only valid tactic in Red Orchestra 2. In my opinion, that is just due to lazy game design.  Something else which I found to be extremely stupid is that not everyone can have access to an automatic weapon. Instead, most players on the server are forced to use a bolt action rifle against their will. This is not only a bad game design choice (since we are forced to use a weapon that we might not want to use), but it also doesn’t make any sense from a realistic point of view. If both sides had access to automatic weapons, wouldn’t they arm all of their soldiers with them? Doesn’t make any sense to use the out-dated weaponry.  I also was disappointed to find that this game is set in the olden days. I find that modern warfare is much more exciting, strategic and enjoyable to play. There are a larger variety of weapons to choose from, alongside a diverse range of vehicles to choose from. I think that the game should have implemented both “olden day” and “modern day” game modes, at least in doing this there would be some variety in the game.  My final point is regarding the kill feed. There seems to be a glitch with the kill feed, in the sense that there is a delay between getting a kill and the kill appearing on the kill feed. In superior titles (such as COD), the kill feed can be used as a means of checking to see if the enemy is dead. For example, if an enemy is in the distance, you can fire a few rounds at the enemy, and then simply check the kill feed to see if they are dead. In Red Orchestra 2, the enemy will often lie down after being shot at. It then becomes very difficult to tell if you have killed the enemy or not, which is often misleading. Fixing the kill feed bug will fix this issue, but the devs do not seem interested in fixing it.  Whatever you do, stay away from Red Orchestra 2. It’s nowhere near as good as others are saying it is. There are a magnitude of poor design decisions which have made this game unplayable. Avoid!

There's no denying that it's a window death simulator. It might even be frustrating for newer players. However there's no better feeling than getting good at this game. Every single kill is an ordeal of skill, stealth and patience, and the payoff is amazing.   My only tip is to look up the differences between axis and allied soldiers so you can avoid commiting friendly fire. Getting shot by teammates is pretty common during freeweekends, and pretty rare during normal matches, mostly thanks to people doing their research. Also look up some basic gameplay tips, very useful.

I have played this game longer than any other. This is because this game has the best multiplayer if you want the ultimate realistic hardcore FPS experience.  The soundscape is excellent. Weapons sound very realistic, whether near, far, or inside a building. Weapon handling (accuracy etc) are still the best I have ever seen in any game (much better than ARMA series in my opinion). There are some neat gameplay mechanics that simulate suppression, and reward teamwork and discourage camper score-whoring. This is probably the only game that really models suppression. Don't bother with the single-player though, its rubbish and the AI is dumb.  When it was released back in 2011, it was rough around the edges with lots of bugs, but now in 2014, with continuous support from the devs, virtually all the problems have been ironed out, and it now runs very stable.  Being realistic and brutal, this is very unforgiving to noobs (and CoD players). Only 1 rifle bullet is needed to kill. Noobs spawn, run forward, and get killed by enemy artillery, or a tank 300m away, or a sniper 200m away, or a machine gunner 150m away, or a maxed out assault trooper 5m away, and never see it coming. Being realistic, machine guns are almost just as accurate as sniper rifles, but it is slightly harder to spot prone enemies without the scope. I am usually the machine gunner, and by a round's end (20min) I may have killed over 80 of them and only died 5 times. That's how ruthless this game is. This is arguably both the game's biggest strengh, and its biggest problem.  This game uses a leveling and unlock system, but it is still quite fair on new players. While fully levelled guns will help (with slightly reduced weapon sway, recoil, reload time, magazine size etc) it is still only 20% of your effectiveness and the remaining 80% is down to your tactical awareness, teamwork, and most of all, your individual skill. That is the most important thing. If you are naturally good, you will start out quite well and only get better as you level up, but if you are not so good at aiming with a mouse, you might always struggle.  The online community is more mature than in most other shooter games. We still get the occasional 12 year old, but not too often. As of Dec-2014 there are still a good range of servers and a good volume of players online (about 1500 sunday night, 300 monday morning). At peak times there are about 5-10 servers with 64 players, and some servers occasionally go over the 64 player limit. The most I have seen is 85, that was epic. In 800 hours of gameplay I have only seen 1 incident of hacking (the artillery hack), and that one was patched out by the devs within days. So, this game has a virtually hack-free environment.  So, this game is too brutal and realistic for many, but if CoD or Battlefield is not cutting it for you, I recommend you try this.

I've had this game long enough, I might as well write a review. Its a great game if you have the patience to learn it. RO2 has a steep learning curve when compared to most fps. If you can see your enemy, he can see you, if you can't see him, he can still see you, if you're behind cover, he can see you, if you just spawned, he can see you, if you're behind him, he can see you. And he will kill you. He will kill you a lot. You will be spawn killed when spawning off your squad leader. You will see a sniper rifle on the ground, and you will spam the pick up key. The pick up key will only work 1/3 of the time. A grenade will land near you and you will spam the prone key. This key will work 3/4 of the time. You will wrestle with the controls as much as you fight your enemy. You will be team killed by free weekenders and people who bought this game on sale. When playing as the americans in RS, you will die 2/3 of the time by aimbotting heatseeking knee mortar nukes, and have your character do an automatic 180 spin to expose his back during a banzi charge. When playing as the russians you will be destroyed by the german's superior machineguns. As the Japanese you will be dominated by the M1 Garand and the flamethrower. As the Germans the russian smg's will cut through you like swiss cheese and their inferior MGs will still give you a run for your money. When you try to join a match with ~3 open player slots, the map will load and only after the map has loaded will you be kicked back to the server browser with the server full message. this happens 1/2 the time. If you are however willing to learn the game and put up with a lot of the stupid stuff that happens way too frequently, this game is EXTREMELY fun. Very tense, very satisfying to do well in. It captures war in a way that few games can, and has lots of small details that add so much to the game. One notable one is the game's unique bolt action mechanic, where, if you choose to turn it on, you have to manually cycle the bolt of the rifle. There are lots of times where you can have awesome Alamo style last stands, as well as adrenaline fueled assaults. Put time into this game. learn from veterans. keep your head down. You'll enjoy it.

Want a game that is so realistic that you have an encounter with a German soldier in a building on your own that is exactly like the knife scene in 'Saving Private Ryan'? Well, this game is what you need. There have been many times that I will always remember in this game. Like this time when me and my squad were running through smoke after being pinned down my an MG42 for about 10 minutes. Someone said that it was 'all clear'. We began to advance down a slope with smoke surrounding us. There was silence, the only noises were our feet hitting the floor. But then, I heard someone next to me say 'Wait! The MG is still.....'. Then a hail of MG fire ripped through the smoke. I dived to the floor. As I looked up, three of my squad members were cut down and one of their helmets rolled towards me. I cowered in a fox hole and began to throw grenades over. It all went slient. I was then that I realised that I was the sole survivor of the suprise attack. I was too scared to stand up. Then I heard footsteps coming my way. Then there he was. A German infantry soldier sprinting towards me with his bayonet at the ready. I managed to shoot him in the leg, but by then it was too late. He embeded the bayonet deep into my chest. As I fell to the floor, I saw the rest of my team, all laying there motionless with their weapons laying by their side. My squad's death was the start of a 1 hour and 30 minute intense, amazing and emotional battle.

One of the best online WWII shooters I've played in a long time. Can really get your heart racing when you're in the front lines. One of the most realistic shooters you'll find as well. Plus, you can pilot vehicles when playing the proper class, which I've never even done (it's pretty complicated). There's a lot I've yet to experience in this game. A few facts about this game:  -You're going to die. A LOT. -You're going to miss your intended target. A LOT. -You're going to be blown up by artillery or grenades. A LOT. -You will get shot and slowly bleed to death. A LOT. -You will shoot your teammates by accident. A LOT.  Here's some tips that I've done on how to avoid any of that:  -Take your time! Think about where you're going to move. Strategize. This isn't f**king Call of Duty, or Battlefield. -Be aware of your surroundings. People hide just about anywhere, and all it takes is one well placed shot for you to be killed. -Stick as close to cover as you can, at all times. Never be out in the open. If any time you can be inside a structure, GO. -Grenades, grenades, grenades! -Bullet drop is a mechanic, keep that in mind when engaging long distance. -Bolt action VS. machine guns in CQB generally won't turn out in your favor. Always try to have the upper hand. Stealth CAN be used if you're smart. -Be sure of your target before firing! This game has friendly fire.  -Don't be a ♥♥♥♥. Always apologize on chat if you TK. Killed teammates can 'forgive' you, and you'll get your points back.   Buy this. Have you bought it yet? No? You will...trust me.

Awesome game. Takes a bit of tinkering with the Settings, which is frustrating but then you play and it's amazing. This isn't a fast paced CoD clone, it's slow going and you have to think through every move you make, or it could be your last. You have limited reinforcements, as well so you have to be careful. Definitely worth the money. Get it. You won't regret it.

To start off this review here is some background. I used to play and very much enjoy the first Red Orchestra and honestly was really excited for RO2 - when it was released I was unfortunately very dissapointed with the game. I knew the bugs would eventually be ironed out but it just felt different...smaller maps, no fluid controls, no tank maps at the start - little things that added up to being flawed game and I'm sure this wasn't experienced by just myself.   Now I've come back to it following the release of Rising Storm and I have to say through Tripwires hardwork and persistance the game is where it should have been in or around the release - the game has been jigged around, tweaked and smoothed to a thoroughly enjoyable experience.  I'll start off by saying the gameplay is relatively slow for a FPS, those of you that have played the predecessor will be used to this. The controls are fluid to suit the style of play with a good intuitive team communication feature to ensure the best possible teamwork out of essentially a game of up to 63 random people.   Aiming, shooting, gun mechanics etc. take a while getting used to but honestly are far easier and far more responsive than that of RO1; this may deter some hardcore sim enthusiasts but if you're looking for a competitive game then this suits perfectly.  Maps are smaller than RO1s, this does have it's pros and cons - pros being it suits competitive games more as you'll realistically not need so many players as the original game did to make a viable game. Cons are from a perspective of a single player really - large maps had a sense of immersion which is missing in RO2 and I hope to see some good community made maps turn up soon. The original had very large tank maps and I have to admit my experience in a tank on RO2 so fast has been extremely limited - however RO2 won't win any prizes if you're looking for a bigger better version of what RO1 did for the tank lover...honestly if you've never played RO1...well lets say it had one of the best tank simulations and this was purely a side part of the main game.  Whilst this review is blunt and to the point I urge anyone who is into FPS to try this, especially if you haven't tried an FPS sim before. They are relentlessly fustrating at the start as you get adjusted to the gameplay speed and die from places unknown in an instant, however it adds to the immersive gameplay, one that is rewarding, team based and skillful.

It only takes about 20 minutes of gameplay to realise this game isnt quite Call of Duty. The game is dark and gloomy,the music is sad. In Call of Duty or Battlefield you feel happy after getting a kill. Your enemy falls to the ground mybe making a grunt or scream. In Red Orchestra/Rising Storm (RO/RS) is different. Let's set up a little scenario. You're playing as a rifleman on the German side. You just ran across the open and now you're tired,you've entered a house to take cover and catch your breath when you hear some footsteps. A quick look at the map confirms there are no allies around,so you step into a corner and zoom in on the entrance nearest to the sound. You crouch down and hear the footsteps get closer. finally,you see the tip of a Mosin-Nagant. You're ready. The Russian fully enters the room and turns towards you. You fire. The bullet hits the Russian in his stomach,the shot is fatal,but he is not dead. He is bleeding out. The injury is too much for him to bandage himself,and all he can see is his screen fading to black. He panics and shoots. You have already clicked a second time to bolt your rifle,you   could   finish him off,but decide to save the extra round,and perhaps not risk being heard for sure. The Russian fires another round. He is bent forwards,his character clutching his stomach. It's rather quiet and you can hear the Russian calling for his mother before falling onto the ground,a blood pool forms around him. You reload your rifle,crouch down and get ready to exit the door he came through. You slowly peek out,check left and right before making a couple more steps into the open. You think it's all clea- *ping* You've just been shot in the head by an enemy you couldn't see. this isnt CoD or Battlefield,there are no killcams or special views showing your killer. This will happen a lot. Have fun.

Rising storm/Red orchestra offers the anti Call of duty FPS. Trip wire interactive takes the classic genre of World War Two and places you on the front lines of major battles of the desolate Eastern front to the beautiful island of the Pacific theater. Realistic locations mixed historically accurate weapons together form a true sense that death is around every corner. Be prepared to die. Nearly every weapon is capable of delivering a killing blow. With this brutal realism you'll quickly finding yourself seeking shelter from all forms of enemy fire, as your character feels the effects of suppression and fatigue. All this detail leads to great multiplayer experience. Although only for people looking for realism and tactics over kill streaks and care packages.

I love this game, but I have to acknowledge the limit of it's appeal. When you could describe the tone of a game by saying, 'It makes Battlefield 3 feel arcadey,' there's definitely a limit to the audience that the game will bring in. While Red Orchestra still has traits from games like the CoD series, things like loadout prestige, and close combat being determined by reaction time and lucky positioning, it definitely pioneered into the wilderness of realistic shooters. Where a normal shooter would give you directional damage markers, and kill-cams, Red Orchestra isn't afraid to kill players with a sniper shot to the heart. Or the pelvis. Or occasionally the calf, if you don't get a tourniquet on it swiftly enough. This devotion to how 'real' combat takes place shapes a sumpremely different game, with players focusing on creeping advances, hunkering down, and setting up fortified locations. Can be a great game if patience is in your skill tree, but otherwise, run-and-gun elsewhere.

Red Orchestra 2 is probably the best and most shining example of how to make a proper Unreal Engine 3-powered PC game. When made for PC, optimized well, and run on adequate hardware, the shoddy and awful console ports that gamers have become accustomed to over the years made with Unreal Engine 3 -- I'm looking at you, Bulletstorm and Gears of War -- seem to simply disappear from memory, and you never look back. This game runs smooth, has awesome shooting and moving mechanics, and isn't for the run-of-the-mill Call of Duty or Battlefield player. Take your time with this one, or you *will* die. Get the game, though, it is worth every penny. Support proper PC developers.

I've started to name this and Rising Storm personally under the title of 'War' as simply, at times I can't describe it as anything but. Barring the horrid singleplayer campaign and Action mode (a more casual mode and the least popular mode in the community) RO2's Multiplayer is balls out amazing. It's terrifying, tense, frequently brutal, realistic, at times hopeless and all around fun.  John Gibson, Tripwire president tried hard to keep the game realistic while also being easy to get into for people not used to such realism and it pays off, helping newbies to not struggle with controls so don't be amazingly afraid of RO2.   The game also has a great first person cover system, weapon mounting system, and even a nice damage system that makes every kill feel earned.   The maps for Heroes of Stalingrad and Rising storm give off experiences so different they're almost different games. Heroes of Stalingrad displays the struggle between the Soviet and German forces between 1941 to 1945, both equally matched albeit fighting on different sides with different weapons across large open, bleak colored battlefields on the snow covered bunkers of russia or the brick, dirt and concrete buildings and battlefields of germany, fights usually either at long range or extreme close range inside buildings.  Rising Storm however shows the Pacific Theatre of World War II, with the Japanese with their superior positioning and more brutally effective tactics (you can plant grenades in the ground like boobey traps and suicide rush for a bayonet stab) against the Americans with their generally superior weapons (You'll get to know the terror of the flamethrower well from the other end) albeit nowhere near the will to do the things the Japanese do, fighting across the tropical battlefields of japenese islands.   And the best part? If you own RO2 you can play Rising Storm's maps albeit stuck to a bolt action rifleman.
But not super heros, be careful.

Satisfies my cravings for a realistic PTSD simulator, I just can't get bored of it.  Red Orchestra 2 is an intense game that demands your attention unless you just want to experience what it's like to be in a meat grinder. You'll need to adopt a very different playstyle to other FPS', suddenly cover is of upmost importance, teamwork becomes neccessary if you want to succeed, it's difficult to play Rambo when you're so fragile.  The quality of your teammates in any of the roles, especially Team Leader/Squad Leaders can greatly change the outcome of each round. Although there's still the usual mix of people, RO2 tends to have a lot of players willing to work together; it's so satisfying when an organised team demolishes the other side.   Bonus points for Tripwire Interactive releasing a bunch of content post-release for no extra cost. I would like to see some of the more common bugs fixed though.   RO2 raises the bar for realism FPS games, now just give me the gritty realism of this mixed with the scale and vehicles of Battlefield 1942 and I'll be happy.

(so THAT’S what the flag on Iwo Jima was about!).  I also know now that WIKIPEDIA LIES! It claims that, during WWII, there were 22-25 million military deaths. What it SHOULD say is that there were 22-25 million military respawns! Silly internet!   So buy this game! Nobody plays it anymore. Focusing on the Battle of Stalingrad and the surrounding operations, both German and Russian content, from the timeline of 1942 to 1943, Heroes of Stalingrad allows you to experience one of the most brutal battles in all of human history with your friends.  For the first time ever in a first person shooter gamers will be able to experience WWII from the German and Russian single player campaign.  Powered by Unreal Engine 3, Red Orchestra 2: Heroes of Stalingrad aims to deliver unrivalled accuracy and attention to detail, along with gritty, vicious combat in multi-player, co-op and solo modes.

Easily one of they best WWII shooters out and likely to still remain so. While multiple games offer brutal realism not many can do it with the intensity and brutality RO2 does. Other similar games suffer from overbearing down time and obtuse controls (arma) and lack of scale and progression. (insurgency) While both games are great in their own right RO2 allows you to instantly become a part of some of the most fierce battles of WWII and immerse yourself in them thanks to its briliant sound design and effective but not frustrating supression. It also manages to remain extremely entertaining whilst acheiving all of this. It is one of the few games where you actually feel as if your playing the choreographed trailer with its seemingly too amazing to be true moments. Whilst other games stage screenshots to entice you, RO2 allows you to actually participate in them as you duck into cover watching your comrade turn into a bleeding stump crying for his mother all the while a group of russians charging through smoke is mowed down by your squad mate. You watch in admiration as he changes his barrel and turn your attention to the Tiger providing support to the defensive hold. You watch in terror as a man runs behind the vehicle, turning it into a catastrophic explosion tossing shrapnel around. Again, another russian charge commences. Your squad mate is not saving you this time, you look at him hoping to see him take control again. He is looking right back at you motionless. You then see in the corner of the screen the cause of his apparent trigger control.   'Give me ammmo you ♥♥♥♥in noob.' Your eviscerated by a russian grenade. You respawn and realise its just a game again.

So far i have about 30 hours into this game, not much I know but it's enough to make me want to cry everytime I hear a firework.   10 of those hours were spent sprinting and hiding.  10 more were spent getting my head blown off at spawn by snipers across the map.  9 were spent watching the startup screen and dealing with nonstop crashes and bugs. And 1 hour was actually spent shooting at enemies.  Long story short, this game has done nothing but amaze me. If it were any other game I probably would have refunded it just because of the amount of bugs I've had but theres a certain masochist desire deep in my heart that kept drawing me back in. I've never seen another FPS do what RO2 has done, the developers have done an amazing job at capturing the feeling of pure terror and confusion of a battlefield. Its not clean and well lit like CoD but gritty and grey, the screen darkens when you're being shot at and half the time you can't tell if the guy in the trench across from you is Russian, German, or simply an agressive bush giving you the stink eye. Dirt and debris fly all around you, bullets ricochet off of walls and you watch in sheer terror as everyone around you is blown apart by artillary or shot down by machine gunners 100 meters away. Now take all of that and image some Russian guy across the globe yelling at you in broken english to run headlong in to everything.   This is Red Orchestra 2 and it is wonderful.

Normally I don't take the time to write lots of reviews on steam, but for this game, I had to. For starters, this game is not only the most realistic World War 2 shooter I have played, but it's also by far the most entertaining. When I first purchased this game, I was actually very worried I would not like it due to the game revolving mostly around very large open maps, but because of the way these maps are created, whether you like it or not, you are forced to pay extremely careful attention to every angle that is around you, and once you adapt to the game, you'll find yourself spotting enemies in small hidden places that you never thought you would be able to see. Been playing the game since release. Never played the first RO, but this game is very fun. Its not like Call of Duty as a lot of people will point out, but that doesn't mean you shouldn't rush in guns blazing, you just got to be careful. The game gets intense, and when playing with the right people, you'll find yourself having a real expirence. There's not a lot of trolling, the community is tiny, so you'll see regulars. The English are always a treat to play with. Bit of a learning curve; expect PTSD to set in around 10 mins.  Please use a mic, don't talk like a tacticool jackass, (ROGER ALPHA TANGO etc.) Use common sense, be brave and GET IN THE POINT!  If you have the patience, you'll have fun. I only play on 'Realism' because that seems to be where the most people are, and you get good fast. I also have the voice acting set to 'Native' so teams only talk in authentic Russain, German, Japanese - helps you really get into it.  If you like WW2, at all, I'd play this game. The Battle for Stalingrad was one of the bloodiest battles in human history, you get to see real locals from the first person (Grain Elevator, Pavlov's House, etc.)  Last piece of info, Russians tend to play for the USSR, snobby folks tend to play as Germans. And ♥♥♥♥ talking between Japanese and USA is godly. People really get into roll-playing in this game.  The game has bugs, it can crash, and does, I have fun regardless. Get it on sale, when its FIVE DOLLARS.

I have roughly 300 + hours in Company of Heroes 2, its not the longest time but I've been around for most of the games life dropping in after every update. I personally loved the allies in WW 2 specifically the Airborne divisions (obviously) but I always found interest in the battles between Germany and Russia, the Germans in CoH2 especially in mp were extremely powerful. When the OKW and USF were added to the game I was delighted that USF had been put in. Though after using them I realized who I was up against... The unstoppable power of the German army then when kitted out with fully auto MP40s and StG 44s along with the dreaded MG42 made it a living nightmare to play as either Russia or America in its unpatched state. I stopped playing after a while it was so bad, luckily you can get the relative same experience from Red Orchestra 2 but in a first person more team based view. Though I find it much more enjoyable to play as 1 man run into mg fire get cut down and try again, rather then see 3 entire sqauds run into mg fire get instantly pinned and completely annihilated by German autogun fire. I like this game and I still love CoH2 pro choice buy for sure!!!  Also the Pacific stuff is cool I guess next stop Vietnam!!

This review focuses on the RO2 portion of the game rather than Rising Storm.  Few games provide such an immersive atmosphere as RO2. Everything from the machinegun fire to the constant barrage of artillery make for some unforgettable gameplay moments. You could play 90% of a match only for your team to be cut down by mg42's, yet make that final push that breaks the enemy's defensive line.  There are 64/64 servers during peak times to join, and the community is 'generally' welcome towards newcomers. If you are looking for a unique and authentic ww2 experience, I highly recommend this game!  ~Das

This is the story of the war in the Pacific through the eyes of a young soldier named TheSpacedIsland  It was our final stand, if we won this defense we would win our campaign, we were deployed from the bunker to our stations, as I followed a fellow soldier and he turned around the corner of a trench he gets pelted by a hail of gunfire, he immediately dies, I turned around and begin to cry while staring at the corpse, I retreat as reinforcements come through, we soon lose alpha, bravo, charlie until we were down to delta, my squad leader had run off like a coward and our sniper had no sight of us while us remaining troops alongside our commander hid in the commanding bunker, I told our only machine gunner to come to where I was to cover the door, he didn't listen, a grenade comes through the window killing our commander, the gunner, and another rifleman, (keep in mind we had run out of reinforcements) all that was left were the two other men on my side of the bunker, our squad leader an our sniper, I heard a banzai cry and saw a jap come through the door, he shot me in the chest, I fall the ground and my eyes begin to darken, the japs run in and I new we were screwed, but then the game timer runs out and we won.....  10/10 Would run out of time again   If arma 3 and cod:world at war had a baby

We thought a lot of things along the long road that brought us to Stalingrad. Here, there is a different time zone: our watch is an hour late.And here, suddenly, birds totally different from ours: kites with a large head and by the strong feathered legs they stand motionless on telegraph poles ; in the evening, gray owls flying over awkwardly and clumsily the road.The sun has become more cruel. Even the steppe has changed, it has disappeared lush vegetation: It is red, parched, overgrown with wormwood and dusty weeds, dry and put Esparto who cowers against the cracked earth. Some oxen dragging carts, a camel is standing in the middle of the steppe. The Volga is approaching. You physically feel the immensity of space invaded by the enemy, a terrible feeling of anguish grips the heart and even prevent you from breathing. This war in the South, this war on the lower Volga, this feeling like a dagger deeply embedded in the flesh, these camels and this flat steppe and parched, announcing the desert approaching, fill with anxiety.  You can no longer back away. Every step back is a disaster, perhaps beyond repair.      Vasilij Grossman

Red Orchestra Experiencie Guide: 1.- Spawn. 2.- Run into the battlefield. 3.- Get killed from ♥♥♥♥ing nowhere. 4.- Spawn. 5.- Walk cautiously into the battlefield. 6.- Get killed from ♥♥♥♥ing nowhere. 7.- Spawn. 8.- Crawl slooooooowly into the battlefield, hiding behind every corner, fallen tree or digged trench. Using smoke to cover your movements and being incredible sneaky. 9.- Get killed from ♥♥♥♥ing nowhere. 10.- Repeat until you understand that war is hell. 11.- Free of your fears, with your comrades by your side, your beard grows, your voice get harsher and your clothes get dirtier. You start to actually listen to the SLs and TL and eventually, you don´t get killed from ♥♥♥♥ing nowhere so often. 12.- Once you are an experienced player, you tried another roles: eventually you lead your own squad, then the whole army, then you win a map, then the war. 13.- You get back to your farm, and alone, you stare in the eyes of your loyal goat Eduvigis, and share with her the one and only lesson that you learned: WAR. IS. HELL. Also, keep your head down, don´t throw smokes in your own lines and put the arty marks behind the capzones.  10/10. War is hell. Also fun.
